channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Trump administration rolls back $2 billion mental health, addiction grant cuts
item.description: Sweeping cuts to mental health and addiction programs worth more than $2 billion are being reversed. After a political backlash from Republicans and Democrats, the grant money will be restored.
item.content:encoded:
Sweeping cuts to mental health and addiction programs worth more than $2 billion are being reversed. After a political backlash from Republicans and Democrats, the grant money will be restored.

(Image credit: Yuki Iwamura/AFP)
item.dc:creator: Brian Mann

item.title: NASA's Crew-11 heads home from space, a month early
item.description: The four members of NASA's Crew-11 mission are heading home from the International Space Station. Their journey is ending a month early due to an astronaut with a "serious medical condition."
item.content:encoded: The four members of NASA's Crew-11 mission are heading home from the International Space Station. Their journey is ending a month early due to an astronaut with a "serious medical condition."
item.dc:creator: Brendan Byrne

item.title: What Venezuela's oil could mean for the industry in Texas
item.description: There's renewed focus on the oil industry since the U.S. seized Venezuela's president. The benefits for Texas, which has many oil companies and the most refining capacity in the U.S., could be mixed.
item.content:encoded: There's renewed focus on the oil industry since the U.S. seized Venezuela's president. The benefits for Texas, which has many oil companies and the most refining capacity in the U.S., could be mixed.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Weber

item.title: Trump administration cuts nearly 2 billion in funding for mental health and addiction
item.description: The Trump administration has cut nearly 2 billion dollars in funding for programs that serve people with mental illness and substance abuse issues. Providers say the cuts are devastating.
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration has cut nearly 2 billion dollars in funding for programs that serve people with mental illness and substance abuse issues. Providers say the cuts are devastating.
item.dc:creator: Brian Mann

item.title: Can federal agents be held accountable? A legal expert weighs in
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with law professor David Cole of Georgetown University about the accountability of federal officers, after an ICE agent shot and killed Renee Macklin Good in Minnesota.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with law professor David Cole of Georgetown University about the accountability of federal officers, after an ICE agent shot and killed Renee Macklin Good in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Fink

item.title: How Trump's 'America First' is upending the world order
item.description: President Trump is dismantling the global system the U.S. built in the 20th century. Foreign policy experts say he wants a world that looks more like the 19th century.
item.content:encoded: President Trump is dismantling the global system the U.S. built in the 20th century. Foreign policy experts say he wants a world that looks more like the 19th century.
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Building strength without weights
item.description: Lifting weights isn't the only way to build strength and muscle. Experts say bodyweight exercises can go a long way and are a great way to get started if you don't feel like going to the gym.
item.content:encoded: Lifting weights isn't the only way to build strength and muscle. Experts say bodyweight exercises can go a long way and are a great way to get started if you don't feel like going to the gym.
item.dc:creator: Will Stone

item.title: Claudette Colvin was a civil rights pioneer. She died this week at 86
item.description: In 1955, 15-year-old Claudette Colvin, a student from a Black high school in Montgomery, Ala., refused to move from her bus seat. The forgotten civil rights activist died this week.
item.content:encoded: In 1955, 15-year-old Claudette Colvin, a student from a Black high school in Montgomery, Ala., refused to move from her bus seat. The forgotten civil rights activist died this week.
item.dc:creator: Matt Ozug

item.title: NPR price-checks 114 items at Walmart
item.description: NPR price-checks 114 items at a Walmart in Georgia to see how costs have changed in a year.
item.content:encoded: NPR price-checks 114 items at a Walmart in Georgia to see how costs have changed in a year.
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh

item.title: Centuries-old 'Frank the Liberty Tree' gets cut down
item.description: People from Florida to Washington want a piece of Frank the Liberty Tree, a huge oak between 250 and 300 years old that was struck by lightning years ago and now must come down.
item.content:encoded: People from Florida to Washington want a piece of Frank the Liberty Tree, a huge oak between 250 and 300 years old that was struck by lightning years ago and now must come down.
item.dc:creator: Frank Morris
